canonical_explanation.text:
Biotechnology deals with the techniques of using living organisms or their products for the benefit of humans. Modern biotechnology is based on two core techniques: genetic engineering (recombinant DNA technology) and bioprocess engineering (maintaining sterile conditions for growing microorganisms on large scale). Genetic engineering involves altering the chemistry of DNA and RNA to introduce these into host organisms to change their phenotype. The key tools include restriction enzymes (molecular scissors like EcoRI that cut DNA at specific palindromic sequences), DNA ligase (joins DNA fragments), vectors (vehicles that carry foreign DNA into host cells, e.g., pBR322 plasmid with ori, ampR, tetR genes), and host organisms (commonly E. coli).

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is an in vitro technique for amplifying specific DNA segments using thermostable Taq polymerase (from Thermus aquaticus), primers, and repeated cycles of denaturation (95 degrees C), annealing (55-65 degrees C), and extension (72 degrees C). Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size through an agarose gel matrix using an electric field; smaller fragments migrate faster. DNA bands are visualised using ethidium bromide staining under UV light. Bioreactors (especially stirred-tank bioreactors) are vessels used for large-scale production of biotechnological products under controlled conditions of temperature, pH, substrate, and oxygen. The steps in rDNA technology include: isolation of DNA, fragmentation using restriction enzymes, isolation of desired DNA fragment by gel electrophoresis, ligation into a vector, transfer into host cell, and selection/screening of transformants using selectable markers.
rules: Restriction enzymes (restriction endonucleases) cut DNA at specific palindromic recognition sequences
EcoRI recognises 5'-GAATTC-3' and cuts between G and A, producing sticky ends with single-stranded overhangs
DNA ligase joins two DNA fragments by forming phosphodiester bonds between them
Vectors (e.g., pBR322) have origin of replication (ori), selectable markers (ampR, tetR), and cloning sites
Insertional inactivation: foreign DNA inserted into a marker gene inactivates it, helping identify recombinants
PCR uses Taq polymerase (thermostable) with repeated cycles: denaturation (95C) → annealing (55-65C) → extension (72C)
Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size — smaller fragments move faster towards the anode (positive electrode)
Ethidium bromide is used to stain DNA in gels; bands are visualised under UV light
Bioreactors (stirred-tank type) maintain optimal conditions for large-scale microbial growth and product formation
rDNA technology steps: isolation → fragmentation → ligation into vector → transfer to host → selection/screening
Competent cells are prepared by treating bacterial cells with CaCl2 to make them take up recombinant DNA
Selectable markers (antibiotic resistance genes) distinguish transformants from non-transformants

questions.question_text: Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that:

options.text: Cut DNA at specific recognition sequences

questions.explanation_correct: Restriction endonucleases (restriction enzymes) are molecular scissors that cut double-stranded DNA at specific palindromic recognition sequences. They were first discovered in bacteria where they restrict the growth of bacteriophages by cutting their DNA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Joining DNA fragments is the function of DNA ligase. Synthesising new DNA strands is done by DNA polymerase. Unwinding the DNA helix is performed by helicase. Restriction enzymes specifically cut DNA at defined sites.

questions.question_text: The recognition sequence of EcoRI is:
questions.explanation_correct: EcoRI recognises the palindromic sequence 5'-GAATTC-3' (reading the same on both strands in 5' to 3' direction). It cuts between G and A on both strands, producing sticky ends (single-stranded overhangs) that can pair with complementary ends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 5'-AAGCTT-3' is the recognition site of HindIII. 5'-GGATCC-3' is recognised by BamHI. 5'-CTGCAG-3' is recognised by PstI. EcoRI specifically recognises 5'-GAATTC-3'.

questions.question_text: A palindromic DNA sequence reads:

options.text: The same on both strands in the same direction (5' to 3')
The same on both strands when read in the 5' to 3' direction on each strand
The same only on the coding strand

questions.explanation_correct: A palindromic DNA sequence reads the same on both strands when read in the 5' to 3' direction on each strand. For example, 5'-GAATTC-3' on one strand and 3'-CTTAAG-5' on the other — reading both in 5' to 3' gives GAATTC. These are the recognition sites for restriction enzymes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not the same direction on both strands; the strands are antiparallel. The sequences are complementary but read the same in their respective 5' to 3' directions. It applies to both strands, not just the coding strand.

questions.question_text:
The








enzyme DNA ligase is used in genetic engineering to:

options.text: Join DNA fragments by forming phosphodiester bonds
Separate DNA fragments on a gel

questions.explanation_correct: DNA ligase is the enzyme that joins two DNA fragments by catalysing the formation of phosphodiester bonds between the 3'-OH end of one fragment and the 5'-phosphate end of the other. It is essential for sealing the nicks after inserting foreign DNA into a vector.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting DNA is done by restriction enzymes, not ligase. Gel electrophoresis separates fragments. PCR uses DNA polymerase (Taq). DNA ligase specifically functions as molecular glue to join DNA fragments.

questions.question_text: pBR322 is a commonly used cloning vector. What does 'ori' in this vector refer to?

options.text: The origin of replication — the sequence where replication begins
The cloning site for inserting foreign DNA
The promoter region for gene expression

questions.explanation_correct: 'ori' (origin of replication) is the specific sequence in the vector where DNA replication initiates. Any piece of DNA linked to ori can replicate within the host cell. The ori also controls the copy number of the linked DNA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotic resistance is conferred by marker genes like ampR and tetR. The cloning site (also called multiple cloning site or polylinker) is where foreign DNA is inserted. The promoter is for gene expression. 'ori' specifically refers to the origin of replication.

questions.question_text: In the vector pBR322, foreign DNA is inserted into the tetR gene. How would you identify the recombinant colonies?

options.text: Recombinants will grow on ampicillin plates but not on tetracycline plates
Recombinants will grow on both ampicillin and tetracycline plates
Recombinants will not grow on any antibiotic plates
Recombinants will grow on tetracycline plates but not on ampicillin plates

questions.explanation_correct: When foreign DNA is inserted into the tetR gene, it causes insertional inactivation of that gene. Recombinants lose tetracycline resistance but retain ampicillin resistance (ampR is intact). Thus, recombinants grow on ampicillin plates but fail to grow on tetracycline plates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growth on both plates would indicate non-recombinants (both genes intact). No growth on any plate would mean the vector itself was lost. Growth only on tetracycline means the ampR gene is disrupted. Insertional inactivation of tetR means recombinants are ampicillin-resistant but tetracycline-sensitive.

questions.question_text: Sticky ends produced by restriction enzymes are useful because they:

options.text: Allow complementary base pairing between fragments cut by the same enzyme
Prevent the DNA from being degraded

questions.explanation_correct: Sticky ends are short single-stranded overhangs produced when restriction enzymes make staggered cuts. These overhangs are complementary and can base-pair with any DNA fragment cut by the same enzyme, facilitating the joining of DNA from different sources by DNA ligase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sticky ends do not permanently seal DNA; ligase is needed. They do not prevent degradation. They are not related to denaturation. Their key utility is enabling complementary base pairing between fragments from different sources.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is NOT required in a cloning vector?

options.text: Cloning sites (recognition sites for restriction enzymes)

questions.explanation_correct: A cloning vector requires an origin of replication (for autonomous replication), selectable markers (for identifying transformants), and cloning sites (restriction enzyme recognition sites for inserting foreign DNA). Genes for antibiotic production are NOT required in a vector; selectable markers confer resistance to antibiotics, they do not produce antibiotics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Origin of replication is essential for vector replication in the host. Selectable markers help distinguish transformants. Cloning sites allow insertion of foreign DNA. Antibiotic production genes are not part of vector design.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The





same restriction enzyme is used to cut both the foreign DNA and the vector DNA in recombinant DNA technology.
Reason: This ensures that both fragments have complementary sticky ends that can be joined by DNA ligase.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct. The same restriction enzyme must be used to cut both the foreign DNA and the vector so that both produce identical sticky ends. The reason correctly explains this — complementary sticky ends from both fragments base-pair with each other, and DNA ligase then seals the gaps to form recombinant DNA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the same enzyme on both DNA sources is standard practice in rDNA technology. The purpose is specifically to generate compatible sticky ends, which the reason correctly states. The reason directly explains why the same enzyme is used.

questions.question_text: In the nomenclature of restriction enzymes, 'R' in EcoRI stands for:
questions.explanation_correct: In EcoRI: 'E' stands for the genus Escherichia, 'co' for the species coli, 'R' for the strain RY13, and 'I' (Roman numeral one) indicates it was the first enzyme isolated from that strain. The 'R' refers to the strain name, not the word 'restriction'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'R' does not stand for restriction, recombinant, or RNA. In restriction enzyme nomenclature, the first letter is the genus, the next two letters are the species, and the following letter(s) denote the strain. Roman numerals indicate the order of discovery.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is correct about blunt ends produced by certain restriction enzymes?

options.text: They are produced when the enzyme cuts both strands at the same position
They can only join with sticky ends
They are easier to ligate than sticky ends

questions.explanation_correct: Blunt ends are produced when a restriction enzyme cuts both strands of the DNA at exactly the same position, leaving no single-stranded overhangs. Examples include enzymes like HpaI. Blunt ends can be joined by DNA ligase but less efficiently than sticky ends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blunt ends do NOT have single-stranded overhangs; that describes sticky ends. Blunt ends can join with other blunt ends, not only sticky ends. They are actually harder to ligate than sticky ends because they lack complementary overhangs for base pairing.

questions.question_text: The selectable markers ampR and tetR in pBR322 help in:

options.text: Selection of transformants and identification of recombinants
Cutting the DNA at specific sites
Transfer of DNA into host cells

questions.explanation_correct: The ampR (ampicillin resistance) and tetR (tetracycline resistance) genes in pBR322 serve as selectable markers. They help select transformants (cells that have taken up the plasmid survive on antibiotic plates) and identify recombinants (insertional inactivation of one marker gene).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Replication is controlled by the ori region, not selectable markers. Cutting DNA is done by restriction enzymes. DNA transfer uses methods like heat shock or electroporation. Selectable markers are specifically for selection and screening purposes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following can serve as a cloning vector?
questions.explanation_correct: Plasmids are small, circular, extrachromosomal DNA molecules found in bacteria. They can replicate autonomously and are widely used as cloning vectors because they can carry foreign DNA into host cells and replicate along with the host genome.
questions.explanation_incorrect: mRNA is a transient molecule and cannot replicate autonomously. Ribosomes are protein synthesis machinery. Histones are DNA-packaging proteins. Plasmids are the most commonly used vectors in genetic engineering.

questions.question_text: PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) requires all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation_correct: PCR requires template DNA (to be amplified), two DNA primers (short synthetic oligonucleotides complementary to the target sequence), Taq DNA polymerase (thermostable enzyme), and deoxyribonucleotides (dNTPs). Restriction enzymes are NOT required for PCR.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Template DNA is essential as it provides the sequence to be amplified. Primers define the start and end of the region to be amplified. Taq polymerase extends the primers. Restriction enzymes are used for cutting DNA, not for PCR amplification.

questions.question_text: Taq polymerase used in PCR is obtained from:
questions.explanation_correct: Taq polymerase is a thermostable DNA polymerase isolated from the thermophilic bacterium Thermus aquaticus, which lives in hot springs. Its ability to withstand the high temperatures (95 degrees C) used in the denaturation step of PCR makes it essential for the reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: E. coli DNA polymerase is not thermostable and would be denatured at PCR temperatures. Agrobacterium is used for gene transfer in plants. Bacillus subtilis is a common soil bacterium. Thermus aquaticus is the specific source of Taq polymerase.

questions.question_text: In gel electrophoresis, DNA fragments migrate towards:

options.text: The cathode (negative electrode) because DNA is positively charged
The anode (positive electrode) because DNA is negatively charged

questions.explanation_correct: DNA molecules carry a negative charge due to the phosphate groups in their backbone. In gel electrophoresis, when an electric field is applied, DNA fragments migrate through the agarose gel towards the anode (positive electrode). Smaller fragments migrate faster than larger ones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA is negatively charged (not positive) due to phosphate groups, so it moves towards the positive electrode. DNA does not migrate to both electrodes or remain stationary. Movement towards the anode is the fundamental principle of DNA electrophoresis.

questions.question_text:
The


 dye used to visualise DNA bands in gel electrophoresis under UV light is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ethidium bromide is an intercalating dye that binds to DNA by inserting between the base pairs. When the stained gel is exposed to UV light, ethidium bromide fluoresces orange, making the DNA bands visible for analysis and documentation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crystal violet is used in Gram staining of bacteria. Methylene blue is a general biological stain. Safranin is a counterstain in Gram staining. Ethidium bromide is the standard DNA stain for gel electrophoresis.

questions.question_text:
In PCR, the








denaturation step is performed at approximately 95 degrees C. The purpose of this step is to:

options.text: Allow primers to bind to the template DNA
Separate the two strands of the double-stranded DNA template

questions.explanation_correct: At 95 degrees C, the hydrogen bonds between the complementary base pairs of the double-stranded DNA template are disrupted, causing the two strands to separate (denature). This exposes the single strands as templates for primer binding and DNA synthesis in subsequent steps.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Primer binding (annealing) occurs at a lower temperature (55-65 degrees C). Taq polymerase is already active and thermostable. DNA synthesis (extension) occurs at 72 degrees C. The 95 degrees C step is specifically for strand separation.

questions.question_text: The correct order of steps in one cycle of PCR is:
questions.explanation_correct: Each PCR cycle consists of three steps in order: (1) Denaturation at 95 degrees C (DNA strands separate), (2) Annealing at 55-65 degrees C (primers bind to complementary sequences on single-stranded template), and (3) Extension at 72 degrees C (Taq polymerase synthesises new DNA strands).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The logical order requires denaturation first (to separate strands), then annealing (primers bind), and finally extension (new strand synthesis). Any other order would not work because primers cannot bind to double-stranded DNA, and extension cannot occur without primers.

questions.question_text: After 5 cycles of PCR, approximately how many copies of the target DNA fragment will be produced from a single template molecule?
questions.explanation_correct: PCR amplification follows an exponential pattern. Starting from one template molecule, after n cycles, the number of copies is approximately 2^n. After 5 cycles: 2^5 = 32 copies of the target DNA fragment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PCR does not produce linear amplification (5 or 10 copies). It is not simply n-squared (25). The exponential amplification formula 2^n gives 32 copies after 5 cycles. This exponential nature makes PCR an extremely powerful amplification technique.

questions.question_text: In gel electrophoresis, which DNA fragments will migrate the farthest from the well?

options.text: Fragments with the most GC content

questions.explanation_correct: In gel electrophoresis, smaller DNA fragments migrate faster and farther through the agarose gel matrix because they can pass through the pores more easily. Larger fragments experience more resistance and migrate slower. This is how fragments are separated by size.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Larger fragments migrate the least distance. GC content does not significantly affect migration in standard agarose gel electrophoresis. The shape (circular vs linear) can affect migration, but size is the primary factor. Smallest fragments travel the farthest.

questions.question_text: A bioreactor is different from a simple flask culture because it provides:

options.text: Only a larger volume for growth
Optimal growth conditions with controlled temperature, pH, oxygen, and agitation
A sterile environment without any nutrients
Only anaerobic conditions for microbial growth

questions.explanation_correct: A bioreactor (such as a stirred-tank bioreactor) provides optimal and controlled growth conditions including temperature, pH, dissolved oxygen, substrate concentration, and agitation. It has an agitator for mixing, an oxygen delivery system, foam control, and sampling ports — all lacking in simple flask cultures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A bioreactor is not merely a larger flask; it actively controls growth parameters. It provides complete nutrient medium, not a sterile environment without nutrients. It can provide both aerobic and anaerobic conditions as needed. The key feature is controlled, optimised conditions.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Taq polymerase is preferred over E. coli DNA polymerase in PCR.
Reason: Taq polymerase is thermostable and remains active even at the high denaturation temperature (95 degrees C) used in PCR.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Taq polymerase is preferred in PCR because it is thermostable — it can withstand repeated heating to 95 degrees C during denaturation without losing activity. E. coli DNA polymerase would be denatured at this temperature. The reason correctly explains why Taq is preferred.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Taq polymerase is indeed preferred (assertion is true). Its thermostability is the specific reason for this preference (reason is true and explains the assertion). E. coli polymerase would be inactivated at PCR temperatures, necessitating enzyme addition every cycle.

questions.question_text: The most commonly used type of bioreactor is:
questions.explanation_correct: The stirred-tank bioreactor is the most commonly used type. It has a mechanical stirrer (impeller/agitator) that keeps the culture medium well-mixed and ensures uniform distribution of nutrients, oxygen, and heat throughout the vessel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sparged, bubble column, and fluidised bed bioreactors are used in specific applications but are not as commonly used as the stirred-tank type. The stirred-tank bioreactor is the standard choice for most biotechnological processes.

questions.question_text:
The





 gel matrix used in gel electrophoresis for separating DNA is typically made of:
questions.explanation_correct: Agarose gel is the most commonly used matrix for DNA electrophoresis. Agarose (a natural polysaccharide derived from seaweed) forms a porous gel when dissolved in buffer, heated, and cooled. The pore size can be varied by changing agarose concentration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Starch gels are rarely used for DNA. Polyacrylamide gels are used for separating smaller DNA fragments or proteins but agarose is the standard for routine DNA work. Cellulose is not used as a gel matrix. Agarose is the standard choice.

questions.question_text: During the annealing step of PCR (typically at 55-65 degrees C), what happens?

options.text: Primers bind to complementary sequences on the single-stranded template
Taq polymerase is added to the reaction

questions.explanation_correct: During the annealing step (55-65 degrees C), the temperature is lowered sufficiently for the short synthetic primers to bind (anneal) to their complementary sequences on the single-stranded DNA template. This provides the starting point for Taq polymerase to begin DNA synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Denaturation occurs at 95 degrees C, not during annealing. DNA synthesis occurs during the extension step at 72 degrees C. Taq polymerase is already present in the reaction mixture from the start. Annealing is specifically for primer binding.

questions.question_text: The first step in recombinant DNA technology is:

options.text: Isolation of the DNA (gene of interest)

questions.explanation_correct: The first step in rDNA technology is the isolation of the genetic material (DNA) from the source organism. The DNA containing the gene of interest must first be extracted and purified before any manipulation can be performed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ligation, transfer into host, and screening are subsequent steps. The logical starting point is obtaining the DNA that contains the gene of interest. Without isolation of DNA, no further steps in rDNA technology are possible.

questions.question_text: Bacterial cells are made 'competent' to take up recombinant DNA by treating them with:
questions.explanation_correct: Bacterial cells are made competent (capable of taking up foreign DNA) by treating them with divalent cation calcium chloride (CaCl2) at a specific concentration. The Ca2+ ions alter the cell membrane, making it more permeable to DNA. The DNA is then forced in by incubation on ice followed by heat shock (42 degrees C).
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaCl is used as a general salt solution. MgSO4 is not used for competent cell preparation. KMnO4 is an oxidising agent not suitable for biological use. CaCl2 is the specific chemical used to make bacterial cells competent.

questions.question_text: To isolate DNA from a cell, which of the following enzymes is used to break open the cell?
questions.explanation_correct: Lysozyme is used to break open bacterial cell walls during DNA isolation. For plant cells, cellulase is used, and for fungal cells, chitinase is used. The enzyme digests the cell wall, releasing the cell contents including DNA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA polymerase synthesises DNA. DNA ligase joins DNA fragments. Taq polymerase is used in PCR. Lysozyme is the enzyme that breaks down bacterial cell walls (peptidoglycan) for DNA isolation.

questions.question_text: After DNA isolation, histone proteins are removed by treatment with:
questions.explanation_correct: Protease enzymes are used to digest and remove histone proteins and other proteins associated with DNA during the isolation process. RNA is removed by RNase, and other purification steps yield clean DNA suitable for manipulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RNase removes RNA contamination, not proteins. Lipase digests lipids. Amylase digests starch. Protease is the enzyme that specifically degrades proteins, including histones associated with DNA.

questions.question_text: In rDNA technology, after the gene of interest is ligated into the vector, the recombinant DNA is introduced into the host cell. This process of introducing foreign DNA into a bacterial cell is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Transformation is the process by which a cell takes up foreign DNA from the external environment. In rDNA technology, competent bacterial cells take up recombinant DNA (vector + gene of interest) through transformation, either by heat shock or electroporation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transduction involves transfer of DNA by bacteriophages. Conjugation is direct transfer between bacteria through pili. Translation is protein synthesis from mRNA. Transformation is the specific term for uptake of naked foreign DNA by competent cells.

questions.question_text: Electroporation is a technique used in rDNA technology to:

options.text: Separate DNA fragments on an agarose gel
Create temporary pores in the cell membrane using electric pulses to facilitate DNA entry
Cut DNA at specific restriction sites

questions.explanation_correct: Electroporation uses brief, high-voltage electric pulses to create temporary pores in the cell membrane. The recombinant DNA enters the cell through these transient pores. The pores reseal after the pulse, trapping the DNA inside the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Separating DNA on gel is electrophoresis, not electroporation. Cutting DNA is done by restriction enzymes. DNA amplification uses PCR. Electroporation specifically creates membrane pores for DNA entry.

questions.question_text:
The





 desired gene fragment separated by gel electrophoresis is cut out from the gel and extracted. This process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Elution is the process of extracting separated DNA fragments from the agarose gel. The desired DNA band is cut out from the gel, and the DNA is extracted (eluted) from the gel matrix using appropriate buffers and techniques for further use in cloning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transformation is the introduction of DNA into host cells. Centrifugation separates substances by density. Precipitation is used to concentrate DNA from solution. Elution specifically refers to extracting the DNA fragment from the gel.

questions.question_text: Blue-white screening is a method used to identify recombinant colonies. It is based on:

options.text: Insertional inactivation of the lacZ gene encoding beta-galactosidase

questions.explanation_correct: In blue-white screening, the vector contains the lacZ gene encoding beta-galactosidase. When foreign DNA is inserted into the lacZ gene, it is inactivated (insertional inactivation). Non-recombinant colonies produce beta-galactosidase, which cleaves the chromogenic substrate X-gal to form a blue product. Recombinant colonies appear white because the enzyme is non-functional.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotic resistance is a different selection method. Temperature sensitivity is not involved. Colony size is not a reliable indicator. Blue-white screening specifically relies on insertional inactivation of lacZ and the X-gal chromogenic substrate.

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of steps in recombinant DNA technology?

options.text: Isolation of DNA → Ligation → Fragmentation → Transfer to host → Screening
Isolation of DNA → Fragmentation by restriction enzymes → Ligation into vector → Transfer to host → Screening
Transfer to host → Isolation → Fragmentation → Ligation → Screening

questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: (1) Isolation of DNA from the source organism, (2) Fragmentation using restriction enzymes to obtain the gene of interest, (3) Ligation of the gene into a suitable vector using DNA ligase, (4) Transfer of the recombinant vector into a host cell, and (5) Selection/screening of transformants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In option A, ligation cannot occur before fragmentation. Options C and D have steps in illogical order. DNA must first be isolated, then cut, then ligated into a vector, then transferred, and finally screened — only option B follows this logical sequence.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Non-recombinant bacteria can be eliminated by plating on antibiotic-containing medium.
Reason: Only bacteria that have taken up the vector (with antibiotic resistance genes) can survive on antibiotic plates.

Select the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true. Non-transformed bacteria (those that did not take up the vector) lack antibiotic resistance and are killed on antibiotic plates. The reason correctly explains this — only bacteria containing the vector (which carries antibiotic resistance genes) survive. This is the basis of selection using selectable markers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion correctly states that non-recombinant (non-transformed) bacteria are eliminated. The reason correctly explains the mechanism — only vector-containing cells have antibiotic resistance. However, note that this selects transformants; further screening is needed to distinguish recombinants from non-recombinants.

questions.question_text: A gene gun (biolistics) is used to introduce DNA into:

options.text: Plant cells by bombarding with DNA-coated gold or tungsten microparticles

questions.explanation_correct: A gene gun (biolistic method/microprojectile bombardment) uses high-velocity gold or tungsten microparticles coated with DNA to bombard target cells, primarily plant cells. The particles penetrate the cell wall and membrane, delivering the DNA directly into the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bacterial cells are typically transformed using CaCl2 or electroporation. Chemical treatment is not biolistics. Electroporation for fungi is a different technique. Gene gun is specifically designed for introducing DNA into cells that are difficult to transform, especially plant cells.

questions.question_text:
In genetic engineering, the





term 'molecular scissors' refers to:
questions.explanation_correct: Restriction endonucleases are called molecular scissors because they cut DNA at specific recognition sequences. Just as scissors cut paper at a specific point, these enzymes precisely cut the DNA double helix at defined palindromic sequences.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA ligase is called molecular glue as it joins fragments. DNA polymerase synthesises DNA. Taq polymerase is a thermostable DNA polymerase for PCR. Restriction endonucleases are the molecular scissors of genetic engineering.

questions.question_text: Agrobacterium tumefaciens is used in genetic engineering because it:

options.text: Naturally transfers T-DNA into plant cells, making it a natural genetic engineer
Can survive at very high temperatures

questions.explanation_correct: Agrobacterium tumefaciens is a soil bacterium that naturally infects dicot plants and transfers a piece of DNA (T-DNA from its Ti plasmid) into the plant genome. Scientists exploit this ability to transfer desired genes into plant cells, making it a natural vector for plant genetic engineering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Agrobacterium is not a human pathogen. While bacteria do produce restriction enzymes, that is not why Agrobacterium is used. It is not thermophilic. Its unique ability to naturally transfer DNA into plant cells makes it invaluable in plant biotechnology.

questions.question_text: Purified DNA precipitates out of solution as fine threads when treated with chilled:
questions.explanation_correct: When chilled ethanol is added to an aqueous DNA solution, DNA precipitates out as fine white threads that can be collected by spooling on a glass rod. Ethanol removes the hydration shell around DNA, causing it to aggregate and precipitate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCl would damage DNA through depurination. NaOH would denature DNA. Distilled water would dissolve DNA, not precipitate it. Chilled ethanol is the standard reagent for DNA precipitation.

questions.question_text:
The





origin of replication (ori) in a vector controls:

options.text: The antibiotic resistance of the host
The copy number of the plasmid in the host cell
The transcription of the inserted gene

questions.explanation_correct: The origin of replication (ori) is the sequence where replication of the plasmid begins. It also controls the copy number — how many copies of the plasmid are made in each host cell. Relaxed ori allows high copy numbers, while stringent ori maintains fewer copies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antibiotic resistance is conferred by marker genes, not ori. Transcription of inserted genes depends on promoters. Selection of transformants uses selectable markers. The ori specifically controls replication initiation and copy number.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a component of a stirred-tank bioreactor?
questions.explanation_correct: A stirred-tank bioreactor contains an agitator system, oxygen delivery system (sparger), temperature and pH control, foam control, and sampling ports. There is no restriction enzyme injection system as restriction enzymes are molecular biology tools, not part of bioreactor design.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Agitator systems ensure uniform mixing. Oxygen delivery (sparger) provides aeration. Temperature and pH control maintain optimal conditions. These are all genuine bioreactor components. Restriction enzyme systems are not part of bioreactor design.

questions.question_text: During DNA isolation, detergent (SDS) is added to the cell lysate. The role of detergent is to:

options.text: Dissolve the lipid components of the cell membrane and denature proteins

questions.explanation_correct: SDS (sodium dodecyl sulphate) is a detergent that dissolves the lipid components of the cell membrane and denatures proteins by disrupting their hydrophobic interactions. This helps in complete cell lysis and separation of DNA from membrane-bound proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA cutting is done by restriction enzymes. DNA precipitation is done by ethanol. DNA amplification uses PCR. Detergent specifically dissolves membranes and denatures proteins during the initial cell lysis step.

questions.question_text:
The


 first restriction endonuclease isolated was:
questions.explanation_correct: HindII was the first restriction endonuclease whose specific recognition and cut site was determined. It was isolated from Haemophilus influenzae Rd. It cuts DNA at a specific point by recognising a particular sequence of six base pairs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: EcoRI was discovered later and is more commonly used in research. BamHI and PstI are other restriction enzymes isolated from different bacteria. HindII holds the distinction of being the first characterised restriction enzyme.

questions.question_text: Which method is used to introduce recombinant DNA into animal cells?

options.text: Micro-injection directly into the nucleus of the animal cell

questions.explanation_correct: Micro-injection is the method used to directly introduce recombinant DNA into the nucleus of an animal cell using a glass micropipette. The DNA is injected into the nucleus using a fine needle under a microscope, bypassing the need for cell wall penetration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Agrobacterium and T-DNA plasmid are used for plant cells, not animal cells. Lysozyme breaks bacterial cell walls and is not a DNA introduction method. Micro-injection is the primary technique for introducing DNA into animal cells.

questions.question_text: If a restriction enzyme cuts a linear DNA molecule at 3 recognition sites, how many fragments will be produced?
questions.explanation_correct: When a restriction enzyme cuts a linear DNA molecule at 3 sites, it produces 4 fragments. For a linear molecule, the number of fragments = number of cuts + 1. So 3 cuts produce 3 + 1 = 4 fragments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2 fragments would result from 1 cut. 3 fragments from 2 cuts. 6 fragments is incorrect. For linear DNA, the formula is: number of fragments = number of restriction sites + 1.

questions.question_text: A student observes that after running gel electrophoresis, the DNA bands are not visible on the gel. The most likely reason is:

options.text: The gel was run for too long
Ethidium bromide staining was not done
The electric field was too strong
The DNA sample was too concentrated

questions.explanation_correct: DNA is colourless and cannot be seen on a gel without staining. If ethidium bromide staining was not performed (or was done improperly), the DNA bands will not be visible. Ethidium bromide intercalates into DNA and fluoresces under UV light, making bands visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Running too long may cause bands to run off the gel but would not make them invisible. A strong electric field might cause smearing but bands would still be visible if stained. Concentrated DNA would produce brighter, not invisible, bands. Missing EtBr staining is the most likely cause.

questions.question_text: Downstream processing in rDNA technology refers to:

options.text: The steps involved in isolating and purifying the desired protein product after biosynthesis
The steps of DNA isolation and fragmentation
The process of transferring DNA into host cells

questions.explanation_correct: Downstream processing refers to all the steps involved in the recovery, separation, purification, and formulation of the desired product (protein) after it has been produced (biosynthesised) by the host organism. This includes cell disruption, filtration, chromatography, and quality control.
questions.explanation_incorrect: DNA isolation and fragmentation are upstream processes. DNA transfer into host cells is part of the cloning procedure. PCR amplification is a molecular biology technique. Downstream processing specifically deals with product recovery and purification.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about vectors used in genetic engineering is INCORRECT?

options.text: Vectors must have an origin of replication to replicate in the host
Vectors should have selectable markers for screening transformants
Vectors must be larger than the host chromosome to carry foreign DNA
Vectors should have unique restriction enzyme recognition sites for inserting foreign DNA

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that vectors must be larger than the host chromosome is incorrect. In fact, vectors (especially plasmids) are small circular DNA molecules, much smaller than the host chromosome. Their small size makes them easy to manipulate, isolate, and introduce into host cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vectors do need ori for replication. Selectable markers are essential for identifying transformants. Unique restriction sites are needed for inserting foreign DNA. The incorrect statement is about vector size — they are smaller than chromosomes, not larger.

questions.question_text: In rDNA technology, after transferring the recombinant vector into E. coli, the transformed cells are plated on agar containing ampicillin. Only some colonies grow. These colonies are:

options.text: Cells that have taken up the vector (transformants)
Cells that have lost all DNA
Dead cells that appear as false colonies

questions.explanation_correct: Colonies that grow on ampicillin plates are transformants — cells that have taken up the vector containing the ampR gene. The ampicillin resistance gene product (beta-lactamase) inactivates ampicillin, allowing only vector-containing cells to survive and form colonies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-transformed cells lack the ampR gene and would be killed by ampicillin. Cells without DNA cannot survive. Dead cells do not form colonies. Only cells that have successfully taken up the vector (with its ampR gene) can grow on ampicillin plates.
